posts.name: Alex Tsekhansky
posts.cooked:
We use a slightly modified CTR template for driving, which works fine.

When we tried using PathPlanner with autobuilder we noticed to our great surprise that it was not working correctly The robot would drive in pretty unusual directions.

Further investigation uncovered that the odometry reset by PathPlanner to the IdealStarting pose sometimes (many times really) does not work, or perhaps is too late.

More specifically, the call to

resetPose(whatever_starting_pose)

either does not happen, or is accepted late by odometry. So, it seems if PathPlanner is too far from starting position, it will try driving to the trajectory starting point - which will be pretty random as it will depend on whatever the odometry thinks you’re at right now.

What we have done so far is to read trajectory’s starting pose and manually reset odometry to it before we start the trajectory. That seems to work fairly well.

But any idea why is still going, and what can we do to fix this? We did not increase frequency of odometry update. But may be do that? Our drivetrain is on a separate CAN bus, meaning increased CAN traffic will not kill the bot.

link_counts.title: PathPlanner going in random directions and speeds

posts.name: Anderson Hall
posts.cooked:
Have you tried reseting odometry in autonInit in robot.java? If you have a function to do this in your drive subsystem you should be able to call it with something along the lines of m_robotcontainer.m_drivesubsystem.resetodo();

along with that, I’d check every log file you can, from DS packet loss, latency, and event list, to PP odo. viewer.

posts.name: Alex Tsekhansky
posts.cooked: The auto-init may work for autos, but not for teleop if we use dynamic trajectories. We will continue investigating. The most pressing question - is it PP that does not send the request, or is it CTR that does not process it on time for some reason?
We had a similar problem. The easiest solution we found was to skip the first cycle of the code.

posts.name: Alex Tsekhansky
posts.cooked: What do you mean by “skip the first cycle”? Like add a wait of 20 or 40 ms before starting driving?

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked:
The odometry pose is updated immediately during the call, you can look at the implementation .

Do you have vision integration? If so, it’s possible that your vision measurement is changing the pose shortly after the resetPose call. If you’re using something like Megatag 2, it’s also possible that your vision measurement calculation used the robot heading before the resetPose call.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.name: Jeffrey Davis
posts.cooked: Can you give an example of this? I can think of several ways this might be done but I’m not sure which one you’re doing.

We do something like this in the command

public void initialize(){ isFirst = true; } public void execute(){ if (isFirst) { isFirst = false; return; } The rest of the command }

posts.name: Alex Tsekhansky
posts.cooked: I do NOT have vision integration yet. So, nothing interferes with it at the moment.

posts.name: Alex Tsekhansky
posts.cooked: Skip the first execute cycle ? Why not just reset the pose and then just add a WAIT command?
We use a slightly different system than commands and can’t add a wait.

posts.name: Alex Tsekhansky
posts.cooked:
What we do right now is basically this -

So, the first command -

reads a trajectory from the file and sets odometry to the first pose.

Then we wait for 0.1 sec (which is 5 x 20ms cycles), and then we actually run the trajectory via

RobotContainer.runTrajectoryPathPlannerWithForceResetOfStartingPose(“Blu-BargeToReef11”, true)

The “true” flag there resets the pose yet again.

The actual reset is done as follows:

Obtain the start pose: PathPlannerPath path = PathPlannerPath.fromPathFile(tr); Pose2d startPose = path.getStartingHolonomicPose().get();

call reset

driveSubsystem.setOdometPoseToSpecificPose(startPose);

Which does this:

public void setOdometryPoseToSpecificPose(Pose2d p) { this.resetPose(p); }

The resetPose is a CTR method of the SwerveDrivetrain class that resets odometry

posts.name: Jeffrey Davis
posts.cooked:
Thanks, if I am reading your code right, the call to setOdometryToIdealPoseFromTrajectory and the call to runTrajectoryPathPlannerWithForceResetOfStartingPose end up calling setOdometryPoseToSpecificPose and resetPose with the path from pathplanner, .1 second apart.

Set it’s set the pose, wait .1s, set the pose again, and then go.

Is this working for you now or is it still an issue?

posts.name: Alex Tsekhansky
posts.cooked:
It seems to be working now But we spent about 2 weeks troubleshooting it.

And yes, your assessment of the code is correct

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked:
Okay, I see quite a few issues that would cause your observed behavior.

First, the reason you weren’t seeing the odometry reset is because it’s currently reset on construction of AutoBlu2Coral , which as you’ve written only happens once in the entire robot program, rather than resetting the pose at the start of command execution. This is why adding the first InstantCommand calling setOdometryToIdealPoseFromTrajectory seems to fix the issue; that’s actually resetting the pose when the command sequence starts to execute. The correct way to write the code is to have runTrajectoryPathPlannerWithForceResetOfStartingPose return:

or otherwise completely separate resetting the robot pose from following the path. Note that AutoBuilder.followPath(path) does not reset the odometry pose.

PathPlanner also has an AutoBuilder.buildAuto(str) function that returns a command that resets the robot pose to the initial pose and then follows an auto path, although I’m not sure how easily you can make use of it with how you chain together several paths.

Lastly, it looks like you may not be handling path flipping correctly. PathPlanner’s AutoBuilder.buildAuto() does, as does AutoBuilder.resetOdom() .

As a side note, once you have everything working, I would recommend taking some time to clean up some of the duplicate APIs and excessively long function names. Improving code readability and reducing complexity makes it much easier to find and fix issues, and it prevents bugs from sneaking past you. That means other teams and CSAs can more reliably provide support, and it will prevent some headaches of your own if you run into an issue at a competition (where you do not get a lot of debugging time).

Another side note, I found these issues using simulation and setting breakpoints . In particular, I noticed that I was never hitting a breakpoint during auton on the line of code that resets the pose, but if I restarted the robot code, then I would hit it once. I would recommend taking full advantage of simulation to find these kinds of issues.

posts.name: Alex Tsekhansky
Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked: I think that works, although AutoBuilder.followPath() might already flip the path. Easiest way to verify is to test in simulation; you can swap which alliance you’re on in the sim GUI while in the “Disconnected” state, and you can connect AdvantageScope to sim to view your robot pose and target pose.

posts.name: Alex Tsekhansky
posts.cooked:
First, your suggestion on

Commands.sequence(AutoBuilder.resetOdom(initialPose)

is the only one that works reliably. We had a first day of first competition today. So, I can attest to the fact that all other ways simply did not work.

Second, the path flip as I described did not really work, but we will do more testing after our first competition is done on Sunday.
